poll.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: the process of finding out what people think about something by asking many people the same question, or the record of the result
poll.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: A recent poll found that 80% of Californians support the governor.
Polls indicate that education is the top issue with voters.
Labour is ahead in the polls.
The latest public opinion poll showed that 25% of us consider ourselves superstitious.
poll.translation[0].definitions[1].defin: the process of voting in an election, or the number of votes recorded
poll.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: Labour won the election with 40% of the poll.
The result of the poll won’t be known until around midnight.
poll.translation[0].note_box[0].sections: A similar poll was carried out among academics in the United States.
A poll taken last month gave the Democrats a seven-point lead.
The poll was conducted with a sample of 1,023 adults.
Polls show that older voters are most concerned about economic issues.
Our poll found that 29 percent rated his performance as good.
The poll results are very encouraging.
A recent opinion poll showed strong support for the government.
The exit polls said that 46 percent of women had voted for Obama.
In most popularity polls, he is in fourth or fifth place.
Local polls show him leading by only two or three points.
Labour soon regained its lead in the polls.
The president's standing in the polls declined sharply.
The good news is that we are ahead in the polls.
At the moment the Democrats are trailing in the polls.
poll.translation[1].definitions[0].defin: to ask a lot of people the same questions in order to find out what they think about a subject
poll.translation[1].definitions[0].examp: 18% of the women we polled said their husbands had a drinking problem.
poll.translation[1].definitions[1].defin: to get a particular number of votes in an election
poll.translation[1].definitions[1].examp: Labour polled just 4% of the vote.
poll.translation[2].definitions[0].defin: an occasion when a large number of people are asked questions, to find out about the public’s opinions or behaviour
poll.translation[2].definitions[0].examp: MORIconducted a poll among senior managers to get their views on taxation.
A recentopinion poll put him in third place.
According to our poll, Scandinavians buy shares more than other Europeans.
poll.translation[2].definitions[1].defin: an election to choose a government or a political representative
poll.translation[2].definitions[1].examp: The ruling Social Democrats suffered their worst defeat at the polls in 60 years.
In Oklahoma, voters may go to the polls (=vote in an election) as early as September.
poll.translation[2].definitions[2].defin: an occasion when the members of a company vote for or against something in a meeting
poll.translation[2].definitions[2].examp: Both directors were elected after a poll of shareholders.
poll.translation[2].definitions[3].defin: the number of votes recorded at an election
poll.translation[2].definitions[3].examp: The winning party must gain at least 50% of the poll.
poll.translation[3].definitions[0].defin: to try to find out about the public’s behaviour or opinions by questioning a large number of people
poll.translation[3].definitions[0].examp: 47% of office workers polled said that eye strain was a serious concern.
